Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Supporting Students' Proof Practices Through Quantitative Reasoning in Algebra

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this CAREER project led by Amy Ellis at the University of Wisconsin is to explore the hypothesis that a curricular focus on quantitative reasoning in middle grades mathematics can enhance development of student skill and understanding about mathematical proof. The project is addressing that hypothesis through a series of studies that include small group teaching experiments with students, professional development work with teachers, and classroom field tests of curricular units that connect quantitative reasoning and proof in algebra.

Work of the project will produce: (a) insights into ways of unifying two previously disconnected lines of research on quantitative reasoning and proof; (b) models describing realistic ways to support development of students' proof competencies through quantitative reasoning; (c) improvement in students' understanding of algebra through engagement in proof practices based on quantitative reasoning; (d) insights into middle-school students' thinking as they negotiate the transition from elementary to more advanced mathematics; and (e) increased understanding of teachers' knowledge about proof and their classroom practices aimed at helping students progress towards understanding and skill in proof.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes from Supporting Proof in Algebra through Reasoning with Quantities have made an impact on the field of education in four ways: a) by improving knowledge about students' learning of function; b) by contributing to the knowledge base of the influence of quantitative reasoning on students' algebraic understanding and proof production; c) by contributing to the knowledge base and methodology on learning trajectories; and d) by contributing to the knowledge base on effective teacher implementation of conceptually-based curricular activities.

The first set of findings regards students' learning of function, in particular, linear, quadratic and exponential function. Quadratic and exponential function are under-researched topics, typically focusing on upper level high school students and university students. The findings in both areas identified a number of student misconceptions, challenges, and difficulties, and also identified teachers' difficulties in both understanding and fostering students' function understanding. Linear, quadratic, and sometimes exponential functions are actually introduced in middle school, but there existed no research prior to our study about middle school students' learning of exponential function, and the research on quadratic function was minimal at that level. Our findings have contributed to the research base of students' learning of algebra, and filled a gap in our understanding of how students learn about non-linear functions. We identified how student learning builds on experiences with linear function, and how instructional moves can foster that learning. 

The second set of findings regards the influence of reasoning with quantities and their relationships on students' learning of function and their abilities to create deductive arguments. Quantification is the process of conceptualizing an object or event (such as a car) and an attribute of that object (such as how far the car traveled) so that the attribute has a unit of measure (such as feet). Thus quantities are people's conceptions of measurable attributes, such as distance, length, time, volume, or temperature. Our findings contribute to the growing body of research on the value of situating student learning within quantitatively-rich situations. We introduced linear function through an exploration of gear ratios, we introduced quadratic function as a relationship between the length and area of rectangles that grow while keeping their height/length ratios, and we introduced exponential function as the relationship between height and time for a plant that doubles in height every week. Our findings indicated that when reasoning in quantitatively rich situations, students are able to construct more robust arguments that rely on generalized examples and deductive chains of reasoning. In addition, by thinking with quantities and their relationships, we found that students are able to develop a covariational perspective to function, which can be more flexible than a correspondence-only perspective. Furthemore, by relying on the quantitative context, students are able to more flexibly shift between the covariation and correspondence views, supporting the development of appropriate algebraic expressions and equations for functional relationships.

Our third set of findings are specific to learning trajectories and their construction, which is an area of research enjoying increased attention due to the Common Core State Standards in mathematics. Research on learning trajectories has been almost exclusively situated in early childhood and elementary level mathematics. We have pushed this methodology up into the functions literature and have produced empirically-based learning trajectories for linear, quadratic, and exponential functions. Furthermore, by exploring how to build a learning trajectory from a series of related studies, we have elaborated a methodology for refining a learning trajectory in order to accont for multiple data sets across multiple populations. 

Our fourth set of findings addresses the need to scale up what we have learned about reasoning with quantities and supporting students' understanding of function and algebra. It is important that teachers are able to take research findings and implement more effective instruction in their own classrooms. We developed a set of research-based curricular materials, and we shared these materials with teachers who then implemented the functions units in their own classrooms. Our analysis of these implementations revealed a better understanding of the particular types of teacher moves and instructional practices that support students' conceptual understanding in algebra. We then developed a framework to articulate the types of moves that operate in relation to one another to support students' meaningful engagement in algebraic reasoning. We have made these curricular materials on linear, quadratic, and exponential function freely available to teachers, accompanied by supporting materials to help teachers with using them in the classroom. We have also partnered with individual teachers, schools, and districts to support implementation of these units in classrooms, and have also shared our findings more broadly with teacher audiences across the nation in workshops, talks, and practitioner journals.

These findings offer contributions to the field of education in terms of content-based knowledge of student learning, methodological advances in the creating of learning trajectories, and pedadogical implications for teacher education.
